dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear about your experience immigrating in 1965. What was that like for you?

dialogue_content.original_text: I was just 20 years old back then.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Leaving my home in Italy was hard, but the prospect of new opportunities in America was so enticing.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like it was a really big step to leave everything behind at such a young age. How did you adjust to life in America once you arrived?

dialogue_content.original_text: Well, it wasn't easy at first.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: People were kind, and I found a job as a seamstress in a local shop.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like finding that job was a significant moment for you. How did your work as a seamstress evolve over time?

dialogue_content.original_text: Working as a seamstress was comforting because it was a skill I brought with me from Italy.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: So when did things change, and you became a union representative?

dialogue_content.original_text: It was in the late 70s, I was well into my 30s then.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: Becoming a union rep allowed me to fight for fair wages and better working hours.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been empowering to stand up for your colleagues. What was it like being a union representative?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: It truly was empowering. I felt a strong sense of responsibility because I knew that people were counting on me.

dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like advocating for your colleagues was a big responsibility. Were there any particular challenges you faced as a union representative?

dialogue_content.original_text: One of the biggest was negotiating with management.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: But every small victory, like securing a pay raise, made it all worthwhile.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been hard. Were there any specific negotiations or victories that stand out in your memory?

dialogue_content.original_text: It was around 1982, and the shop owners wanted to cut back on our health benefits.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: But I managed to secure an agreement that not only maintained our benefits but also improved them slightly.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear about how your career transitioned from being a union representative to teaching sewing. What led you to make that change?

dialogue_content.original_text: Transitioning to teaching was a natural step for me.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: So when you look back on your journey, how do you feel about it all now?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: Reflecting on my journey fills me with a lot of gratitude and pride. It's been a fulfilling life.

dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: Before we finish, what final lesson or piece of wisdom would you like to share?

dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
dialogue_content.original_text: I would say, never underestimate the power of perseverance and kindness.
